item.description: Everyone should pull one great practical joke in their lifetimes. This one was mine, and I think it's past the statute of limitations. The s...

item.title: Does Baby Have Hat
item.description: It’s April Cools! Last year I wrote about parenting, in 2023 about friendship bracelets. and in 2022 about cocktails. This year it’s a bit of a meandering stroll through some ideas around mutual aid and self-reliance. Maternity wards If you walk around the maternity ward at Kaiser Permanente’s Sunnyside medical center outside of Portland, Oregon, you might notice the same two things I did. The first was how many signs were posted on the hallways describing the maternity team’s KRs and displaying charts showing that they are meeting them.

item.title: Random Numbers Included
item.description: I've recently worked on a PRNG API for TigerBeetle, and made a surprising discovery! While most APIs work best with half-open intervals, for(int i = 0; i < n; i++), it seems that random numbers really work best with closed intervals, ≤n.

item.title: Script for Updating Open WebUI in a Proxmox LXC
item.description: A really simple script for those that, for some odd reason, decided to run the Open WebUI server from inside a LXC. The problem I really like the interface in Proxmox and i prefer it than dealing with Portainer for some services that are more accessed. This is the case for Open WebUI, which I use daily. The problem I faced was the update process of the service, which I knew little about.

item.title: Read Weird Things
item.description: I used to have a mental block against casually reading things that weren’t designed to be casually read, like old papers, textbooks, documentation, etc. If I was going to read for enjoyment, I’d read blogs or popular science/fiction books. Not sure why. Over time, I’ve met people who read things I’d never think to read. I’ve gotten a lot of value from copying them, so I’m sharing my thoughts here.

item.title: The Good, The Bad, and The AI: One Month of Coding with Cursor | EclecticMind
item.description: After a month with Cursor, I’ve seen its power to streamline coding—helping me write faster, navigate new tech, and stay productive in short bursts—but it’s not without quirks. This post dives into both the wins and the frustrations.

item.description: Push Notification Hub is an essential internal service that plays a crucial role in the messaging and calling flows within Teams and other platforms. item.title: Leverage GitHub Copilot in Visual Studio Code and ASP.NET Core | BinaryIntellect Knowledge Base
item.description: AI is everywhere. Almost all the leading software development platforms and tools use AI in some of the other way. As an ASP.NET Core developer wanting to use Visual Studio Code for your development, you must know how to leverage the power of GitHub Copilot from within the VS Code editor. In this series of articles I am going to explain a few features of GitHub Copilot the can help you increase your productivity, efficiency and code quality.

item.title: 2025-04-01-final-final-FINAL-V2.go
item.description:
Some very important news on the future of the show in this episode. You'll get answers to important questions like:
What does the future of the show look like? Who are the next, big ticket, guests? What's a SegFault? Why does my knee hurt? Why do fools fall in love? Does this look infected to you? Any many more. So definitely make a point of listening to this episode... all the way to the end, too.
There's no transcription for this episode, as it's all breaking news and I didn't have the time to get one completed before the time of release.
Show Notes Welcome friends to The Modern .NET Show; the premier .NET podcast, focusing entirely on the knowledge, tools, and frameworks that all .NET developers should have in their toolbox. We are the go-to podcast for .NET developers worldwide, and I am your host: Jamie "GaProgMan" Taylor.
In this episode, I'll talk you through a slight change of direction for the show. But more on that in a moment. Let's listen to the intro music for a little longer before I wrap up this intro.
Anyway, without further ado, let's sit back, open up a terminal, type in `go mod init github.com/golang-show` and we'll dive into...
Supporting the Show If you find this episode useful in any way, please consider supporting the show by either leaving a review (check our review page for ways to do that), sharing the episode with a friend or colleague, buying the host a coffee, or considering becoming a Patron of the show.
Full Show Notes There are no full show notes for this episode, friends. I'm sorry for that, but it's the nature of the game when you're releasing breaking news.
I'll try and get a transcription completed in the next few days, so watch out for that.
Music Used In This Episode This contains some copyright free music during the interstitials. Each of the pieces of music (linked below) were created by some incredibly highly skilled invididuals. If you liked the music we used, check out links to the them below:
"Ascend (sped up)" by Alex-Productions "Golden" by HoobeZa "Mellow" by HoobeZa Supporting the show: Leave a rating or review Buy the show a coffee Become a patron Getting in Touch: Via the contact page Joining the Discord Remember to rate and review the show on Apple Podcasts, Podchaser, or wherever you find your podcasts, this will help the show's audience grow. Or you can just share the show with a friend.
And don't forget to reach out via our Contact page. We're very interested in your opinion of the show, so please get in touch.
You can support the show by making a monthly donation on the show's Patreon page at: https://www.patreon.com/TheDotNetCorePodcast.
Music created by Mono Memory Music, licensed to RJJ Software for use in The Modern .NET Show
item.author: (Jamie Taylor)

item.title: Get the hell out of the LLM as soon as possible | sgnt.ai
item.description: Don’t let an LLM make decisions or implement business logic: they suck at that.
